profileAlternative.name: Brian Anderson
profileAlternative.headline: Senior Software Engineer and Rust "Expert"
profileAlternative.summary:
I'm a passionate engineer with diverse skills, a history in systems programming, software validation, programming languages, and open source community building. I co-founded the Rust programming language and its sister project, the Servo web browser. When I'm part of projects that stimulate my imagination I tend to make good things happen. I am agonizingly self-aware and always improving.

Some consider me one of the world's foremost experts on the Rust programming language. I'm reluctant to agree (let's chat about imposter syndrome), but I'm writing it here because it sounds impressive.

I generally like talking to people and companies using Rust, but I'm not actively seeking a new gig right now.

positions.title: Senior Research Engineer
positions.description:
The stuff I'm building [1] is cool. Like, really, amazingly cool. First of all, I and a bunch of my friends are creating a new systems programming language called Rust [2]. It does things that no other language does, it's open source, has a large and growing community of contributors, and people dig it.

It gets much better though. So get this: we're taking that language, Rust, and using it to build an *entirely new* web browser from scratch, called Servo [3]. This thing is architected from the ground up to be massively parallel, unlike any other web browser in existence, and it's going to deliver.

It's unbelievably audacious and I love it.

[1]: http://brson.github.io/rust-stuff.html
[2]: http://rust-lang.org/
[3]: https://github.com/servo/servo

positions.title: Just a Kid
positions.description:
Ahhh, while I'm reminiscing, some of my early background:

- My dad was into microcomputers. Thanks dad <3.

- My awesome 7th grade math teacher taught me to program in QBASIC. I loved QBASIC. There was a moment in time where it was my world. As far as I knew GOTOs were just fine.

- From QBASIC I taught myself C++. Pointers were hard. OO was hard. C++ is too hard ;) In college I clearly remember thinking I was a C++ expert. Lol at my young self - nobody's a C++ expert.

- I was completely obnoxious in my high school programming classes, knowing more than my peers and teacher, and making a point of it.

- I was often the only member of my high school programming team. We competed locally. I recall during one competition proudly being the only team to succeed at implementing a BASIC interpreter; and I did so in QBASIC by sending the input back through the QBASIC interpreter. It was totally cheating and I was totally disqualified.

- I created the website for my high school jazz band (I was the drummer). It was the wild west nineties and I rendered the animated navigation bar with POV-Ray, and streamed audio with RealAudio. It was neat but terrible.

- I was paid (in parking stickers) to create my high school's website. I'm sure it was awful and unmaintainable and they definitely replaced it quickly.

- For extra credit in Spanish class I submitted a game written in VB6 that had an interactive map of the world, in which you did ... something ... something to do with Spanish surely. In retrospect I wish I had cared to actually learn Spanish.

- A parent of a high school peer hired me to work for his tiny basement company building websites for others using his proprietary tooling. That was my first real job.

Some good memories there. That was mostly high school - I was the kid who knew computers. In college I mostly drank hard and listened to heavy metal.

Brian is an excellent software architect and engineer -- I learned new things every time I read Brian's code for handling errors and edge cases before they impacted his programs' performance. But on a team of expert technologists, what really sets Brian apart is his unwavering devotion to communicating considerately and empathetically, even on a large and often frustrating open source project. What impresses me about Brian's consistently empathetic communication is that it doesn't just come naturally to him -- he's built these skills intentionally and thought really hard about how to do so, which means that he's able to explain and teach them, such as in one of my favorite writeups of constructive techniques for better discourse at http://brson.github.io/2017/04/05/minimally-nice-maintainer.

received.text:
Brendan was one of the earliest contributors to the Rust programming language, and remains a highly-respected member of that community. Though he has contributed a great deal of quality code to Rust in the graphics and numerical computing domains, he has made an even greater impact as a role model for others, always friendly, welcoming, and eager to help.

bjz has a lot of fans in #rust and at Mozilla Research.

Xueying and I worked very closely for several years, during which she was responsible for the implementation of multiple mobile projects of increasing scope and complexity. She was my mentor and I benefited greatly from her experience and patience. During this time we participated in one of those large-scale, overly ambitious enterprise integration projects that give engineers nightmares, but she was brilliant at navigating the constantly shifting and contradictory business requirements to successfully deliver the product. Her history in both software development and project management gives her the versatility to fill many roles.
